Ι should scarce- ly have thought it possible to write four let- tere, much less four hundred, to a friend in whom one was deeply interested, without in- troducing questions and allusions which would have enabled the reader in some degree to pic· ture to himself his occupation and habits. On the part of Atticus at any rate there was no such want of sympathy, as may be gathered from the pointed questions in reference to his friend’s doings, which are noticed and answered by Cicero in almost every letter. But on the other side there is certainly no response of sympathy. The allusions os Cicero to his friend's occupations are of the most meagre and unsatisfactory kind, shuffled as a rule into three or four lines at the end of a letter, and withal so devoid of interest that to the end of the chapter Atticus is little else to the reader than an epistolary dummy, on which are hung the trophies of Cicero’s lif . If this view of his character be the cor- rect one, we are at no loss to account for his own statement, that, with the exception of Atticus, he had no real friend. And in this lay one of the great secrets of his weak- = nese, for it is most certain that no man ever needed thern more. Cicero was not one who could mark out his path and pursue it inde- pendently of counsel and advice.
